results.title: Epilepsy: first aid for seizures
results.creator_credit: Ernie Steck, Paul Eide and University of Minnesota
results.brief_description: Dispels the myths that surround epilepsy and informs on the facts. Provides information on how to recognise the various forms of epilepsy - petit mal, grand mal, partial seizure and post-ictal state. The treatment required for these various stages of epilepsy is also noted. Narrated by Mark frost. Suitable for middle and upper secondary and tertiary levels.

results.title: Entities
results.creator_credit: OOM Creative, MORE Studio, Greg More (OOM Creative), Pete Brundle (MORE Studio) and James Sandri (MORE Studio)
results.brief_description: Entities is a time-based data visualisation of visitors collecting objects and exploring Constellations. These actions are translated into graphical forms to show what’s being collected, as well as highlighting Constellations that share connections.

constellations_primary.name: Future visions
constellations_primary.description: Entities is a time-based data visualisation of visitors collecting objects and exploring Constellations. These actions are translated into graphical forms to show what’s being collected, as well as highlighting Constellations that share connections.

results.creator_credit_for_label: OOM Creative, MORE Studio, Greg More (OOM Creative), Pete Brundle (MORE Studio) and James Sandri (MORE Studio)
results.description:
We leave a trace whenever we interact with a digital system: a thread of data that lingers like a ghost within a machine.

Entities is a time-based data visualisation of visitors collecting objects and exploring Constellations. These actions are translated into graphical forms to show what’s being collected, as well as highlighting Constellations that share connections. Each time an object is collected, the visualisation updates in real-time to create a dynamic living map of our visitors’ journey: the more people in the space, the more active it becomes. Created by code and contemporary web technologies, Entities encourages visitors to discover new objects and artworks by seeing what others are collecting in the gallery over time.

Created by code and contemporary web technologies, Entities encourages visitors to discover new objects and artworks by seeing what others are collecting in the gallery over time.

results.title: Entertaining with Isabel Jones
results.brief_description: Isabelle Jones, cookery broadcaster and journalist, shows you step-by-step how simple cooking and entertaining really is. This 60-minute video features four different menus for six people. Over 25 tried and tested, delicious recipes in the accompanying cover booklet. Table setting ideas, lots of cooking tips, quick and easy methods. Rated: G

results.title: Entertaining angels
results.creator_credit: Michael Rhodes, Elwood Kieser and Paulist Pictures
results.brief_description: ‘Entertaining Angels’ is based on the true life of Dorothy Day, a radical journalist who lived in New York writing about the plight of America’s homeless. She has an early love affair with a co-worker which results in a traumatic abortion that sees her move to the coast to be alone. While staying at the beach Dorothy (Moira Kelly) comes across and old friend and the two fall in love. It is at this time that Dorothy begins to question her faith after some close contact with one of the nuns who runs a shelter for the disadvantaged. Dorothy falls pregnant to Foster and although happy for a while, she refuses to give up her religion and he refuses to marry, once again Dorothy is alone but ready to move back to the city. Dorothy and her daughter are baptized Catholics and Dorothy resumes her career as a journalist, only this time starting her own paper, “The Catholic Worker” after meeting Peter, a French social activist. Dorothy combines her journalism and charity at home, offering the homeless a soup kitchen, shelter and office where she can work on the paper. This is an inspiring film that was made on a relatively small budget by Paulist Pictures who also brought us ‘Romero’.

results.title: Enter the dragon
results.creator_credit: Robert Clouse, Paul Heller, Fred Weintraub, Concorde Productions and Warner Bros Pictures
results.brief_description: One of the biggest martial arts epics ever filmed. Bruce Lee, determined to avenge the murder of his sister, enters the island fortress of crime warlord Han. Lee staged his own fighting sequences in the movie and the sequences are thrilling in their timing and execution. ‘Enter the dragon’ was Lee’s last film and his untimely death at a young age, a few weeks after the film’s completion had made this a landmark film of its genre.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Robert Clouse, Paul Heller, Fred Weintraub, Concorde Productions and Warner Bros Pictures

results.title: Ennui = L'Ennui [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: Cedric Kahn, Paolo Branco, Centre National de la Cinematographie, Canal+, Madragoa Filmes, Ima Films and Gemini Films
results.brief_description: Martin is a philosopher suffering from ennui - listless at work, disinterested in films or literature, disenchanted with life and estranged from his ex-wife. One night he meets an elderly painter, who dies shortly afterwards whilst making love to his teenage muse, Cecilia. Intrigued by Cecilia’s hold over the artist (who painted her obsessively) Martin starts to meet Cecilia every afternoon for uncommitted sex. At first Martin is aroused by Cecilia’s bland conversation and apparent feeble-mindedness but soon Cecilia’s detachment starts to obsess him and, unable to control his burgeoning neuroses, Martin’s life spins out of control. The enigmatic Cecilia, an inscrutable and monosyllabic presence to Martin’s excessive verbiage, exacerbates his feverous (and increasingly demonic) need to penetrate her calm. But Martin’s methods to destabilise Cecilia’s mystique are sexual violence and petty torments. Kahn’s roving camera, occasionally hand-held with sudden drops in lighting, suggests a documentary rather than a drama as he explores the futility of Martin’s masochistic irrationality. As a study of sexual obsession, “L’Ennui” pays detailed if detached attention to the sex act, deliberately failing to eroticise the couplings that at times appear utterly joyless to the protagonists. But at two hours and with a cyclical narrative, this film proves, at times, quite trying. Cast includes Charles Berling and Sophie Guillemin. In French with English subtitles.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Cedric Kahn, Paolo Branco, Centre National de la Cinematographie, Canal+, Madragoa Filmes, Ima Films and Gemini Films

results.title: English at Work. - Eps. 31-33.
results.creator_credit: Richard Jasek, Michael Karris, Diane Sundin and SBS-TV
results.brief_description: In “Training for work” advice is given to sole parents who are thinking of rejoining the workforce. Particular attention is paid to the need for adequate childcare and retraining opportunities. The second episode “Driving safely” warns against irresponsible driving behaviour, especially drink- driving and speeding. In “Making job decisions” we follow young people making choices about the work they would like to do, as well as established workers attempting to retrain for different careers.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Richard Jasek, Michael Karris, Diane Sundin and SBS-TV

results.title: Energy. Ep. 3. New sources
results.creator_credit: George McQuilkin, Jane Treiman, Anthony Morris and Churchill Films
results.brief_description: Examines the potential and limits of new technologies, including solar, fusion and geothermal. Presents an argument for developing a variety of options. Stresses societies need to develop ways of using less energy. Suitable for upper secondary level.

results.title: Enjoying Australasian wine
results.brief_description: The wine industries of Australia and New Zealand are producing wines of world class quality. To discover just how we are achieving this phenomenal success, we visit major wine growing areas in the two countries to hear from the growers and winemakers, followed by wine-tasting segments with Michael Hill-Smith, Australia’s only “Master of wine”. The areas visited are: the Hunter Valley and Mudgee, North-eastern Victoria, South Australia, Western Australia and New Zealand. Introduced by Len Evans.
